segment.source: Capture Images of Hard Disk Partitions Using DISM
segment.target: Capture Images of Hard Disk Partitions Using DISM

segment.source: Capture Images of Hard Disk Partitions Using DISM
segment.target: Capture Images of Hard Disk Partitions Using DISM

segment.source: Capture Images of Hard Disk Partitions Using DISM
segment.target: Capture Images of Hard Disk Partitions Using DISM

segment.source: You can use the Deployment Image Servicing and Management (DISM) tool to capture an image of your hard disk for deployment and save it as a Windows® image (.wim) file.
segment.target: You can use the Deployment Image Servicing and Management (DISM) tool to capture an image of your hard disk for deployment and save it as a Windows® image (.wim) file.

segment.source: To see how this information applies to Windows, system, and recovery partitions, see Capture and Apply Windows, System, and Recovery Partitions.
segment.target: To see how this information applies to Windows, system, and recovery partitions, see Capture and Apply Windows, System, and Recovery Partitions.

segment.source: Prerequisites
segment.target: Prerequisites

segment.source: Windows PE.
segment.target: Windows PE.

segment.source: See WinPE: Create USB Bootable drive.
segment.target: See WinPE: Create USB Bootable drive.

segment.source: A reference computer.
segment.target: A reference computer.

segment.source: You can create a reference computer by deploying Windows, and then removing the computer-specific information from the system.
segment.target: You can create a reference computer by deploying Windows, and then removing the computer-specific information from the system.

segment.source: For more information, see Sysprep (Generalize) a Windows installation.
segment.target: For more information, see Sysprep (Generalize) a Windows installation.

segment.source: Step 1: Determining Which Partitions to Capture
segment.target: Step 1: Determining Which Partitions to Capture

segment.source: This table shows the types of partitions that you must capture and those that are managed automatically.
segment.target: This table shows the types of partitions that you must capture and those that are managed automatically.

segment.source: Partition type
segment.target: Partition type

segment.source: Should you capture this partition?
segment.target: Should you capture this partition?

segment.source: System partition (BIOS system partition or EFI System Partition)
segment.target: System partition (BIOS system partition or EFI System Partition)

segment.source: Optional.
segment.target: Optional.

segment.source: If only a simple set of partition files is required, you don’t have to capture this partition.
segment.target: If only a simple set of partition files is required, you don’t have to capture this partition.

segment.source: Microsoft Reserved partition (MSR)
segment.target: Microsoft Reserved partition (MSR)

segment.source: No.
segment.target: No.

segment.source: Primary partitions (Windows partitions, utility partitions)
segment.target: Primary partitions (Windows partitions, utility partitions)

segment.source: Yes.
segment.target: Yes.

segment.source: Extended partition
segment.target: Extended partition

segment.source: No.
segment.target: No.

segment.source: Logical partitions (Windows partitions, utility partitions)
segment.target: Logical partitions (Windows partitions, utility partitions)

segment.source: Yes.
segment.target: Yes.

segment.source: You can capture and apply images between partitions on BIOS-based and UEFI-based computers, because the Windows image isn’t affected by the firmware.
segment.target: You can capture and apply images between partitions on BIOS-based and UEFI-based computers, because the Windows image isn’t affected by the firmware.

segment.source: For more information, see Capture and Apply Windows, System, and Recovery Partitions.
segment.target: For more information, see Capture and Apply Windows, System, and Recovery Partitions.

segment.source: Step 2: Assign Drive Letters to Partitions
segment.target: Step 2: Assign Drive Letters to Partitions

segment.source: If any of the partitions you want to capture don’t already have a drive letter assigned, assign a letter using the DiskPart tool.
segment.target: If any of the partitions you want to capture don’t already have a drive letter assigned, assign a letter using the DiskPart tool.

segment.source: Start your reference computer by using Windows PE.
segment.target: Start your reference computer by using Windows PE.

segment.source: At the Windows PE command prompt, type to open the DiskPart tool.
segment.target: At the Windows PE command prompt, type to open the DiskPart tool.

segment.source: Select the hard disk with the command.
segment.target: Select the hard disk with the command.

segment.source: For example,
segment.target: For example,

segment.source: View the partitions with the command.
segment.target: View the partitions with the command.

segment.source: For example,
segment.target: For example,

segment.source: Select the partition with the command.
segment.target: Select the partition with the command.

segment.source: For example,
segment.target: For example,

segment.source: Assign a letter to the partition with the command.
segment.target: Assign a letter to the partition with the command.

segment.source: For example,
segment.target: For example,

segment.source: Type to return to the Windows PE command prompt.
segment.target: Type to return to the Windows PE command prompt.

segment.source: For more information, see the DiskPart Help from the command line, or Diskpart Command line syntax.
segment.target: For more information, see the DiskPart Help from the command line, or Diskpart Command line syntax.

segment.source: Step 3: Capture Partition Images using DISM
segment.target: Step 3: Capture Partition Images using DISM

segment.source: Capture images for each customized partition.
segment.target: Capture images for each customized partition.

segment.source: At the Windows PE command prompt, capture the images by using the DISM command together with the /captureImage option.
segment.target: At the Windows PE command prompt, capture the images by using the DISM command together with the /captureImage option.

segment.source: For example,
segment.target: For example,

segment.source: For more information about using the DISM tool to capture an image, see DISM Image Management Command-Line Options.
segment.target: For more information about using the DISM tool to capture an image, see DISM Image Management Command-Line Options.

segment.source: Step 4: Save Images to the Network
segment.target: Step 4: Save Images to the Network

segment.source: Save your .wim files to your network or another safe location.
segment.target: Save your .wim files to your network or another safe location.

segment.source: Connect to your distribution share by using the net use command.
segment.target: Connect to your distribution share by using the net use command.

segment.source: For example,
segment.target: For example,

segment.source: If prompted, provide your network credentials.
segment.target: If prompted, provide your network credentials.

segment.source: Copy the partitions to your network share.
segment.target: Copy the partitions to your network share.

segment.source: For example,
segment.target: For example,

segment.source: Next Steps
segment.target: Next Steps

segment.source: After the image is captured and stored, you can:
segment.target: After the image is captured and stored, you can:

segment.source: Mount it to your reference computer for modification.
segment.target: Mount it to your reference computer for modification.

segment.source: For more information, see Mount and Modify a Windows Image Using DISM.
segment.target: For more information, see Mount and Modify a Windows Image Using DISM.

segment.source: Split the file into smaller files.
segment.target: Split the file into smaller files.

segment.source: For more information, see Split a Windows Image (WIM) File to Span Across Multiple DVDs.
segment.target: For more information, see Split a Windows Image (WIM) File to Span Across Multiple DVDs.

segment.source: Apply the images to a destination computer.
segment.target: Apply the images to a destination computer.

segment.source: For more information, see Apply Images Using DISM.
segment.target: For more information, see Apply Images Using DISM.

segment.source: Service the image.
segment.target: Service the image.

segment.source: For more information, see Service a Windows Image Using DISM.
segment.target: For more information, see Service a Windows Image Using DISM.
